Title.evidence: A randomized controlled trial was performed between June 2010 and October 2012 at Zhongshan Hospital, Fudan University.

Trial_Design.evidence: A randomized controlled trial was performed between June 2010 and October 2012 at Zhongshan Hospital, Fudan University.

Participants.evidence: 51 patients who presented with ARCO Stages I to IIIB bilateral osteonecrosis were potentially eligible for inclusion, and 33 patients were identified as meeting the inclusion criteria and offered enrollment and randomization.

Intervention.evidence: Bilateral hips of each patient were randomly assigned to surgical options: one side was treated with core decompression and the contralateral side was concurrently treated with fibular grafting.

Objective.evidence: What is the effect of core decompression and fibular grafting on vascularity of the femoral head as measured by single-photon emission CT (SPECT)/CT?

Method_Outcome.evidence: SPECT/CT examinations were performed to quantify radionuclide uptake to evaluate vascularity of the femoral head before treatment and at 6 and 36 months after surgery.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Bilateral hips of each patient were randomly assigned to surgical options.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 33 patients were identified as meeting the inclusion criteria and offered enrollment and randomization. Six patients declined to participate at the time of randomization, leaving a final sample of 27 participants (54 hips).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Six patients (22%) were lost to followup.

Result_Outcome.evidence: By SPECT/CT analysis, decompression-treated hips had lower vascularity than fibular-grafted hips at 6 months (68 % ± 6% versus 95% ± 5%; mean difference, −27%; 95% CI, −32% to −23%; p < 0.001) and 36 months (57% ± 4% versus 91% ± 3%; mean difference, −34%; 95% CI, −37% to −32%; p < 0.001).
